title: $100 Million Was Once Big Money for a Start-Up. Now, It’s Common.
abstract: Known as a mega-round in Silicon Valley, large-scale fund raising is producing a frenzy around tech companies with enough reach and momentum to absorb a large check.

title: How a Fake Group on Facebook Created Real Protests
abstract: The Black Elevation page held rallies, posted videos and encouraged the fight against racism. Whoever ran it even interviewed a job applicant.

title: The Unlikely Activists Who Took On Silicon Valley — and Won
abstract: Facebook and Google made billions mining personal data, and fought off anyone who threatened to stop them. Then came a challenge in their own backyard.

title: Uber Picks N.S.A. Veteran to Fix Troubled Security Team
abstract: Matt Olsen, the former general counselof the National Security Agency, will replace Joe Sullivan, who was fired after the disclosure of a data breach.

title: Tesla Directors Do Damage Control After Elon Musk Tweets
abstract: Tesla’s board of directors has hired multiple outside law firms, and a number of board members and Tesla employees have urged Mr. Musk to stop posting on Twitter.

title: Finding It Hard to Focus? Maybe It’s Not Your Fault
abstract: The rise of the new “attention economy.”

title: Elon Musk’s Effort to Take Tesla Private to Get Board Oversight
abstract: Three independent members of the board will have “full power and authority” to evaluate any privatization efforts proposed by Elon Musk, the chief executive.

title: Turkish President Calls for Boycott of U.S. Electronics Including the iPhone
abstract: The remarks by President Recep Tayyip Erdogan come as the country grapples with a worsening economic crisis and a widening diplomatic dispute with the United States.

title: Make Your Own Message Folders in Windows 10
abstract: If the standard set of folders that comes with the Windows 10 Mail program are not enough, you add and delete your own.

title: This Company Keeps Lies About Sandy Hook on the Web
abstract: The father of a victim of the Sandy Hook shooting has tried to erase lies about his son from the internet, but Automattic, which runs WordPress.com, says “untrue content is not banned.”

title: Tesla Board Surprised by Elon Musk’s Tweet on Taking Carmaker Private
abstract: The chief executive is said to have written his Twitter post last week in haste. But he said Monday he had Saudi financial backing for a buyout plan.

title: What Chrome Means by ‘Not Secure’
abstract: Google’s recent update to the browser warns users when websites aren’t automatically protecting their communication.

title: Banks and Retailers Are Tracking How You Type, Swipe and Tap
abstract: Biometrics are moving way beyond fingerprints: To fight fraud, companies are building databases on people’s behaviors and movements.

title: Richard Russell Stole a Plane in Seattle and Crashed It. How’d He Learn to Fly?
abstract: Flight instructors and aviation experts were split on whether video games and simulations could prepare someone to operate a real plane.

title: Google-Facebook Dominance Hurts Ad Tech Firms, Speeding Consolidation
abstract: The investment of venture capital money into ad tech start-ups is falling sharply, helping push a wave of acquisitions.

title: Strong Women on the March at Seattle Art Fair
abstract: In a city where power, gender and technology converge, artists ask hard questions about diversity.

title: Inside Twitter’s Struggle Over What Gets Banned
abstract: The social media company provided a rare look inside a policy meeting as it struggled with criticism that it left up posts from the conspiracy site Infowars and its creator, Alex Jones.

title: The Security of Cellular Connections
abstract: That free Wi-Fi network may not be so free if it is unsecured and someone hijacks your data. Your phone’s cellular data connection offers more protection.

title: The Week in Tech: Infowars and China’s Great Firewall
abstract: As exasperating as the debate about tech giants’ role in policing content may be for Americans, people in China can only dream of having such discussions.

title: What’s the Right Number of Taxis (or Uber or Lyft Cars) in a City?
abstract: Technology has made it easier to identify and manage the optimal supply, but it also depends on which problem you’re trying to solve.

title: Facebook Banned Infowars. Now What?
abstract: Slippery-slope fears about mass censorship by social media platforms are probably overblown. But many valid questions remain.

title: Riders Wonder: With Uber as New York’s Plan B, Is There a Plan C?
abstract: Customers mull a world with fewer Ubers, a day after New York became the first major American city to cap the growth of for-hire vehicles.

title: Wanted: ‘Lost Einsteins.’ Please Apply.
abstract: Pioneer, an experimental fund, is using the Silicon Valley model to find and nurture people who have talent but lack opportunity.

title: Samsung Unveils New Galaxy Note Smartphone Amid Slowing Sales
abstract: Samsung on Thursday took the wraps off the Galaxy Note9, its latest big-screen smartphone, even as it confronts a saturated market for the devices.

title: How to Look for Proof of a Spoof
abstract: If your friends are getting email messages you didn’t send, someone may be forging your address on spammy activities.

title: Tech Companies Banned Infowars. Now, Its App Is Trending.
abstract: Days after Google, Facebook and Apple removed Infowars content, the app from the right-wing conspiracy site has surged in downloads.

title: Playing Catch-Up With Walmart, Amazon Offers Digital Grocery Pickup at Whole Foods
abstract: Amazon said its Whole Foods stores would let customers order groceries online and pick them up in person. Walmart already offers that service at nearly 1,800 stores.

title: Uber Hit With Cap as New York City Takes Lead in Crackdown
abstract: The City Council voted on Wednesday to cap Uber vehicles and other ride-hail services.

title: The Internet Trolls Have Won. Sorry, There’s Not Much You Can Do.
abstract: When it comes to online comments and discourse and what you can do to limit their toxicity, you only have a certain amount of power. The real leverage lies with the tech companies.

title: Why ‘Fred’ Is the Best Friend of Economics Writers
abstract: Neil Irwin, who covers economics for The Upshot, often turns to “Fred,” a site full of economic data that is maintained by the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis.

title: Give Long-Distance Windows Help From the Comfort of Your Own Home
abstract: Built-in utilities and third-party programs let you connect and control another computer so you can provide personal tech support to family and friends over the internet.

title: Why a Cap on Uber in New York Would be a Major Blow for the Ride-Hail Giant
abstract: The New York City Council is expected to vote on Wednesday on a cap for Uber vehicles and other ride-hail services.
